comment.author: 69798423@N03
comment._content:
Richard landed in Alexandria in Egypt on 5th September 1915 having attested at Manchester on 28th January 1915 with the service number 2798. This initially puts him with the 1/6th Battalion Royal Scots, a TF Battalion, they landed at Marseilles 16th May 1916 and by the 15th June 1916 they had amalgamated with 1/5th Battalion to become 5/6th Battalion.

SDGW Info:

Birth Place: Manchester
Residence: Oldham
Death Date: 3 May 1917
Death Location: France & Flanders
Enlistment Location: Manchester
Rank: Private
Regiment: Royal Scots (Lothian Regiment)
Battalion: 2nd Battalion
Number: 275719
Type of Casualty: Died of wounds
Theatre of War: Western European Theatre

comment.author: 64288588@N05
comment._content: At the time of the 1901 census Richard's father was not at home but his mother was described as a Tripe Shop Owner. At that time they lived at 207 Allerton Road, Bradford. Richard's older brother Thomas F Owen had been born in Bradford circa 1880 and his parents married there so perhaps there were family conections. Nor was Mr Owen at home at the time of the 1911 census. Georgina was described as Traveller (Provisions, etc.), in other words a Travelling Sales Woman, which is quite an unusual occupation for a woman. Thomas Frederick Owen was a Railway Clerk and Richard Henry Stanley, at the age of 17, was a Shop Assistant at Oldham Equitable Co-Operative Society. (The building is Grade II listed and currently occupied by Carpet World on Huddersfield Road www.britishlistedbuildings.co.uk/en-388905-oldham-equitab...). Perhaps because Georgina was away from home a lot, the family employed a House Keeper, 36yr old Annie Roberts. They occupied 5 rooms at 10 Bridson Street, Clarksfield, Oldham, Lancashire. Bridson Street still stands and is a row of red-brick two-bedroomed terrace houses. Richard and his brother likely occupied one bedroom whilst Georgina and Annie shared the other. www.belvoirlettings.com/bridson-street-clarksfield-oldham... There is a family tree for the Owens on www.ancestry.co.uk with photographs of Georgina (nee Wicks) who died in 1947, along with others of Richard in uniform and with his brother when they were young. In my opinion the two photographs of Richard do not tally. The tree shows that Mr Owen was born in 1866 in Shifnal, Shropshire but gives no date of death. In 1891 the family was living at 9 Heywood Street, Congleton, Cheshire and Thomas Owen was described as an Evangelist. So, perhaps his was also an itinerant profession which saw the family moving from place to place as he sought to convert people.
